entry.et: Middle English bordure, from Anglo-French, from border to border, from Old French bort border, of Germanic origin; probably akin to Old English bord board

def.dt: :an ornamental design at the edge of a fabric or rug
:a narrow bed of planted ground along the edge of a garden or walk a border of tulips
:a plain or decorative margin around printed matter
:to touch at the edge or boundary :bound borders the city on the south
:to lie on the border the United States borders on Canada
:to approach the nature of a specified thing :verge borders on the ridiculous
:any of a breed of medium-sized sheepdogs of British origin noted for their herding abilities
:any of a breed of small terriers of British origin having a harsh dense coat and close undercoat
:a stria of microvilli on the plasma membrane of an epithelial cell (as in a kidney tubule) that is specialized for absorption
